list.item: S. J'avois craint, tu avois craint, il avoit craint. P. Nous avions craint, vous aviez craint, ils avoient craint.

list.head: 2. Pluperfect.
list.item: S. J'eu craint, tu eus craint, il eut craint. P. Nous eumes craint, vous eutes craint, ils eurent craint.

list.head: Future.
list.item: S. Je craindrai, tu craindras, il craindra. P. Nous craindrons, vous craindrez, ils craindront.
I shall, or I will fear, &c.

list.head: Present.
list.item: S. QUE je craigne, tu craignes, il craigne. P. Nous craignions, vous craigniez, ils craignent.

list.head: 1. Imperfect.
list.item: S. Je craindrois, tu craindrois, il craindroit. P. Nous craindrions, vous craindriez, ils craindroient.
Or, I should, would, could fear, &c.

list.head: 2. Imperfect.
list.item: S. Je craignisse, tu craignisses, il craignist. P. Nous craignissions, vous craignissiez, ils craignissent.

list.head: Preter perfect.
list.item: S. J'aye craint, tu ayes craint, il ait craint. P. Nous ayons craint, vous ayez craint, ils ayent craint.

list.head: 1. Pluperfect.
list.item: S. J'aurois craint, tu aurois craint, il auroit craint. P. Nous aurions craint, vous auriez craint, ils auroient craint.
I had, or I would have feared, &c.

list.head: 2. Pluperfect.
list.item: S. J'eusse craint, tu eusses craint, il eust craint. P. Nous eussions craint, vous eussiez craint, ils eussent craint.

list.head: Future.
list.item: S. J'aurai craint, tu auras craint, il aura craint. P. Nous aurons craint, vous aurez craint, ils auront craint.
S. CRains, qu'il craigne. P. Craignons, craiguez, qu'ils craignent.
Fear thou, let him fear. Let us fear, fear you, let them fear.

div.head: Conjugation of Passive Verbs. Conjugation of Passive Verbs.
div.p:
THE Passive Verb in French, as in English, has no Termination that distinguishes it from others, and is only form'd out of the Participle past, of any Active Verb, joyned to the Auxiliary Verb Etre, through all its Moods, Tenses, Numbers and Persons; as,
Je suis aimÃ©e, I am Loved, Elle est aimÃ©e, she is Loved.
Vous Ã©tes emplis, you are filled, elles sont emplies, they are filled.
Nous fumes receus, we were received.
Elle avoit Ã©tÃ© venduÃ«, she had been sold. Ils seront vendus, they will be sold.
Etre craint, to be feared.
Where you must observe, that the Participle varies according to the difference of Gender and Number.

div.head: Conjugation of Neuter and Common Verbs.
div.p: NEuter and Common Verbs, such, as, Badiner, to play the Fool, Palir, to grow pale, Engraisser, to fatten, or grow fat, Rougir, to make red or blush, are Conjugated all along like the Active.
â€ Except these thirteen Neutral Verbs, viz.

list.item: Entrer, to go or come in.
Monter, to go or come up.
Passer, to pass or go by.
Sortir, to go or come out.

div.p: Whose Compound Tenses are Conjugated by the Auxiliary Etre, as the Passive Verbs, and not by the Verb Avoir, as the Active; as you may see in the following Example.

list.head: Indicative. Present. J'Arrive.
list.item: Perfect. Je suis arrivÃ©, ou Ã©e.
2. Pluperfect. Je fus arrivÃ© ou Ã©e.

list.head: Conjunctive.
list.item: Perfect. Je sois arrivÃ©, ou Ã©e.
1. Pluperfect. Je serois arrivÃ©, ou Ã©e.
2. Pluperfect. Je fusse arrivÃ©, ou Ã©e.
Future. Je serai arrivÃ©, ou Ã©e.

div.p: *1. Note that in these Verbs, as in the Passive, the Participle varies according to the difference of Gender and Number, except when it comes before the Infinitive of any Verb, where it remains still the same; as,

list.item: Il est allÃ© voir. He is gone to see.
Elle est allÃ© voir. She is gone to see.

div.p: * 2. These two Verbs, Passer and Monter, with their Compounds, Repasser, to pass again, Remonter, to go or come up again, may be Conjugated in their Compound Tenses, either with the Verb Etre, or with the Verb Avoir.

* 3. These six, Aller, Venir, Sortir, Accourir, Mourir, Naitre, are not only Conjugated by the Verb Etre, but do vary besides from the Rule in several Tenses, as we shall shew in the Conjugation of Irregular Verbs.

div.head: Conjugation of Reciprocal Verbs.
div.p: A Verb Reciprocal, is commonly nothing else, but a Verb Active, used with these Pronouns, me, te, se, in the Singular Number, nous, vous, se, in the Plural; but so that all its Compounds, Tenses, are Conjugated as the foregoing Neutral, by the Verb Etre.
'Tis true, that some Verbs are always Reciprocal, and those areâ–ª known by the Infinitive Mood, where the Pronoun se goes ever before them; as, se repentir, to Repent, se moquer, to Laugh at.
The following Example of the first Conjugation, will teach you how to Conjugate any Verb Reciprocal.

div.head: Se Lever, to Rise.

list.head: Indicative.
list.item: Present.S. Je me leve, tu te leves, il se leve. P. Nous nous levons, vous vous levez, ils se levent.

list.head: Conjunctive
list.item: Present.S. Que je me leve, tu te leves, il se leve. P. Nous nous levions, vous vous leviez, ils se levent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. LEve toi, qu'il se leve.
P. Levons nous, levez-vous, qu'ils se levent.

div.p: * The Participle past, admits in Verbs Reciprocal, the same difference as we have marked in the foregoing Neutral Verbs.

div.head: Of Verbs Impersonal.
div.p: A Verb Impersonal is so called, not because it expresses to Person at all; but first, because it is used often to represent Natural Actions, which have no relation to any Man's Person; as, il pleut, it rains, il fait chaud, it is hot; And secondly, because it is Conjugated by the Third Person singular only.

Of Verbs Impersonal some are absolutely such; as, il ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , one must, il importe, it matters, it imports; most come from Verbs Personal; as, il fair f â€¢ oid, it is cold, il est ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , it is true, on assure, 'tis affirm'd, on pense, 'tis thought, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
vend, they sell.

There are two Particles in French, viz. Il and On, which commonly go before the Verb Impersonal; Il is used sometimes with the Verbs that signifie a Natural Action; as,
Il pleut, it Rains. Il tonne, it thunders.

And sometimes with those that have relation, either to the Manners or Actions of Men; as,
Il faut, one must. Il me souvient, I remember. Il sied, it becomes.

But on is only used in this last Notion, and keeps the signification of the word it derives from, viz. Homme, Man; and being joined with any Verb, renders it Impersonal, through all its Tenses and Moods, except the Infinitive; as,
On dit, they say, or 'tis said. On fait, they do. On croit, they believe, or 'tis believed.

The Letter (L) is often put before on, when the word that goes before it, ends by a Vowel; as,
Si l'on veut, if they will. Ie veux que l'on m'ecoute, I will be listen'd to.

But when the word that comes next after the Particle on begins by an l, then on must be without it; as,
Si on l'estime, if they have an esteem for him.
* Some Verbs Impersonal, distinguish the Persons both in the Singular and Plural Numbers, by the means of Personal Pronouns; as,

list.item: Il vous importe, it concerns you.
Il me faut aller lÃ , I must go thither.
Il fa â€¢â€¢ loit qu'ils y allassent, they should have gone thither.
Vous souvient il? Do you remember?
Il luy vint dans l'esprit, it came into his mind.

div.head: Of the Conjugation of Verbs Impersonal.
div.p: VErbs Impersonal are Conjugated by the Th â€¢ rd Person of the Singular Number, in all Moods and Tenses, according to the Character of their Conjugation.

div.head: Â§ 1. There are some of the First; as,
div.p: Which are Conjugated in the following manner.

list.head: Indicative.
list.item: Imperfect.Il grÃ©loit, it hailed or did hail.
Perfect.Il a grÃ©lÃ©, it has hailed.
1. Pluperfect.Il avoit grÃ©lÃ©, it had hailed.
2. Pluperfect.Il eut grÃ©lÃ©, it had hailed.

list.head: Conjunctive.
list.item: Present.QU'il grÃ©le, that i â€¢ hail.

1. Imperfect.Il grÃ©leroit, it would, co â€¢â€¢â€¢
or should hail.

2. Imperfect.Il grÃ©last, it hailed or w â€¢â€¢
hail, &c.
Perfect.Il ayt grÃ©lÃ©, it has hailed.
1. Pluperfect.Il auroit grÃ©lÃ©, it had hailed.
2. Pluperfect.Il eust grÃ©lÃ©, it had hailed.
Future.Il aura grÃ©lÃ©, it shall have hail â€¢â€¢

div.head: Â§. 2. Some are of the Second Conjugation; as,
div.p: On reÃ¼ssit, they succeed. Il souvient, one remembers.
Il vient dans l'esprit, it comes into ones mind.

div.head: Â§ 3. Others are of the Third Conjugation; as,
div.p: Il faut, one must. Il vaut mieux, it is better. Il pleut, it rains. Il y a, there is.
* The Verb, il faut, being the most useful of all Impersonal, we. shall Conjugate it through all its Moods and Tenses.

div.head: Il faut, one must.

list.head: Infinitive.
list.item: Present. FAloir, (which is not in use.)

div.p: This Verb is used four several ways in the French Tongue.

1st. Before the Conjunctive Mood with the Particle ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
which Conjunctive Mood is rendred in English by the
â€¢â€¢â€¢ finitive; as,

Il faul que j'aille, I must go. Il faut que vou â€¢ aimiez, yo â€¢
must love. Il faut que cela soit, that must be.
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
faudroit que cela se fit, that should be done.
And so in all other Tenses and Persons.

2dly. It is used before an Infinitive Mood, either in an
â€¢â€¢â€¢ determined Signification; as,
Il faut faire cela, that must be done.
Or, with these Personal Pronouns, me, te, nous, vous, ce â€¢â€¢
as,
Il me faut faire cela, I must do that.
Il te falloit battre contre lui, you should have fought him.
Il nous faut manger tout cela, we must eat all that.
Il vous faut accorder, you must agree.
And so of other Tenses and Persons.

3dly. It is used before Substantives, either absolutely as,
Il faut de l'argent, Money must be had.

Or with these Personal Pronouns, me, te, lui, nous, v â€¢â€¢
â–ª leur; as,
4thly. It is used sometimes at the end of a Sentence, in this manner; Vous faites ce qu'il faut, you do what is fitting.

div.head: Â§ 4. Lastly, There are Impersonal Verbs of the Fourth Conjugation; as,
div.p: Il suffit, it sufficeth. C'est, it is. Il plait, it pleases. Il sensuit, it follows. Il est, it is. On dit, 'tis said. Il paroit, it appears. Il fait, it is.
* Il fait is used instead of the Verb Etre, either when we speak of the Weather; as,
Il fait bea â€¢ tems, it is fine Weather. Il fait beau soleil, the Sun shines purely.
Or before such Words as these; Bon, Mal, Meilleur, Dangereux; as,
Il fait bon i â€¢ y, it is good being here. Il fait meilleur ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , it is better being there. Il fait dangereux sur mer, it is dangerous being at Sea.
Besides the fore-mentioned Verbs Impersonal, the French use this Pronoun Se Impersonally; as,

Il se mange de bo â€¢ Beuf en Anglet â€¢ rre, there's good Beef eaten in England. Il se boit de bon Vin en France, good Wine is drunk in France, Cela se dit par tout, that is said every where. Cela s'e â€¢ va sa â€¢ s dire, that's to be understood.

div.head: Conjugation of Verbs Irregular.
div.p: IRregular Ver â€¢ s are those whose Conjugation does not follow the common Rule, either by different Terminations, or by the want of some of their Moods, Tenses, or Persons.
There are Irregular Verbs of all Conjugationsâ–ª

div.head: Â§ 1. Irregular Verb of the First Conjugation.
div.p: THO' the First Conjugation comprehend by it self ten times more Verbs than the other three together, yet it has but one Irregular Verb, viz. Aller to go, and its compound S'en aller to go, which follows the form of Reciprocal Verbs in its Neutral Signification, as we have hinted before.

list.head: Indicative.
list.item: Present. S. JE vai, tu vas, il va. P. Nous allons, vous allez, ils vont.
Perfect. Je suis allÃ©, tu es allÃ©, &c.
Future. S. J'irai, tu iras, il ira. P. Nous irons, vous irez, ils iront.

list.head: Conjunctive.
list.item: Present. S. QUE j'aille, tu ailles, il aille. P. Nous ai â€¢ . lions, vous ailliez, ils aillent.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE m'en vai, tu t'en vas, il s'en va. P. Nous nous en allons, vous vous en allez, ils s'en vont.
And so in the other Tenses.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUe je m'en aille, tu t'en ailles, il s'en aille. Nous nous en aillions, vous vous en ailliez, ils s'en aillent.
And so in the other Tenses.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. VAt'en, qu'il s'en aille. P. Allons nous en, allez vous en, qu'ils s'en aillent.

div.head: Â§ 2. Irregular Verbs of the second Conjugation.
div.p: THE Second Conjugation hath no less than Twenty Four, which I shall set down in an Alphabetical Order.

div.head: 1. Bouillir. To boil.
div.p: This Verb is not much in use, besides the Infinitive, and the third Person of the Tenses of other Moods; however, it may be Conjugated thus.

list.head: Indicative.
list.item: Present. S. JE bous, tu bous, il bout, P. Nous bouillons, vous bouillez, ils bouillent.

list.head: Conjunctive.
list.item: Present. S. QUE je bouille, tu bouilles, il bouille.
P. Nous bouillions, vous bouilliez, ils bouillent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. BOu, qu'il bouille. P. Bouillons, bouillez, qu'ils bouillent.

div.p:
Y â€¢ s Compound Rebour â€¢ lir, to boil again, is Conjugated as the
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ .

div.head: 2. Courir ou Courre, To Run.
div.p: THis Verb is Neuter by Nature, yet it has sometimes an Active signification; as, when we say, Courir Fortune, or Courre Risque, To run the hazard, Courre la bague, to run the Ring.

list.head: Indicative.
list.item: Present. S. JE cours, tu cours, il court. P. Nous courons, vous courez, ils courent.

list.head: Conjunctive.
list.item: Present. S. QUE je coure, tu coures, il coure. P. Nous courions, vous couriez, ils courent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. COurs, qu'il coure. P. Courons, courez, qu'ils courent.

div.p: And so are Conjugated its Compounds,
Discourir, to discourse. Encourir, to incur. Parcourir, to run over. Recourir, to fly to. Secourir, to succour. Concourir, to concur.
â€ But Accourir to run to, is Conjugated like the Neutral Verbs, of which we have already spoken.

div.head: 3. Couvrir. To Cover.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE couvre, tu couvres, il couvre.
P. Nous couvrons, vous couvrez, ils couvrent.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE je couvre, tu couvres, il couvre.

P. Nou â€¢
couvrions, vous couvriez, il â€¢
couvrent.

J'a â€¢ e couvert, j'aurois co â€¢â€¢â€¢ vert,
â€¢â€¢ eusse couvert, j'auray couvert, &c.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. COuvre, qu'il couvre, P. Couvrons, couvrez, qu'ils couvrent.

div.p: And so Conjugate its Compounds, Decouvrir, to discover, Recouvrir, to cover again.

div.head: 4. Cueiller, To gather or to pluck.
div.p: This Verb was formerly of the first Conjugation, of which its Present, Imperfect, and Future Tenses of the Indicative, are still.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE cueille, tu cueilles, il cueille. P. Nous cueillons, vous cueillez, ils cueillent.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE je cueille, tu cueilles, il cueille.
P. Nous cueillions, vous cueilliez, ils cueillent.
J'aye cueilli, j'aurois cueilli, j'eusse cueilli, j'aurai cueilli, &c.

div.p: As for its Compounds Recueillir, and Aecueiller, to Receive, they are exactly Conjugated as the simple Cueillir.

div.head: 5. Dormir, To Sleep.

list.head: Indicative. Present. S. JE dors, tu dors, il dort,
list.item: P. Nous dormons, vous dormez, ils dorment.
J'ay dormi, j'avois dormi, j'eu dormi, &c.

list.head: Conjunctive.
list.item:
S. QUE je dorme, tu dormes, il dorme. P. Nou â€¢
dormions, vous dormiez, ils dorme â€¢ t.

div.p: And so are Conjugated its Compounds, endormir to make asleep, &c.

div.head: 6. Faillir, To Fail.
div.p: This Verb is defective, and is not in use in the Present and Imperfect Tenses.

list.head: But they say in the Indicative,
list.item: Je faillis, j'ai failli, j'avois failli, j'eus failli.

list.head: And in the Conjunctive.
list.item: j'aurois failli, j'eusse failli, j'aurai failli.

div.p: Its Compound Defaillir, is little in use besides the Infinitive.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE fuis, tu fuis, il fuit.
P. Nous fuÃ¯ons, vous fuÃ¯ez, ils fuÃ¯ent.
J'aye fuÃ¯, j'avois fuÃ¯, j'eus fuÃ¯.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE je fuie, tu fuies, il fuie.
P. Nous fuiyons, vous f â€¢ iyez, ils fuiyent.
J'ayâ–ª fuÃ¯, j'aurois fuÃ¯, j'eusse fuÃ¯, j'aurai fuÃ¯.

div.head: 8. Hair. To Hate.
div.p: This Verb has nothing Irregular but the three Persons Singular of the Present Indicative. Ie hai, tu hais, il hait, and the Imperative Hai, where h is pronounced with aspiration, and ai as a Dipthongue; in all others places (but the Infinitive) h has no aspiration, and ai is divided; as,
Je HaÃ¯ssois, je HaÃ¯rai, &c.

div.head: 9. Mentir, To Lie, or Tell a Lie.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE mens, tu mens, il ment.
P. Nous mentons, vous mentez, ils mentent.
J'ay menti, j'avois menti, j'eu menti.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: J'aye menti, j'aurois menti, j'eusse menti, j'aurai menti.

div.p: And so is Conjugated its Compound Dementir, to give one the Lie.

div.head: 10. Mourir, To Die.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE meurs, tu meurs, il meurt.
P. Nous mourons, vous mourez, ils meurent.
Je suis mort, j'Ã©tois mort, je fus mort.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE je meure, tu meures, il meure.
P. Nous mourions, vous mouriez, ils meurent.
Je sois mort, je serois mort, je fusse mort, je serai mort.

div.p: This Verb is sometimes Reciprocal in the Present and Imperfect Tenses, to signifie that one is going to die; as,
Je me meurs, je me mourois, &c.

div.head: 11. Offrir, to Offer. 12. Ouvrir, to Open.
div.p: These two Verbs are Conjugated after the manner of Couvrir, to Cover.

div.head: 13. OuÃ¯r, To Hear.
div.p: This Verb grows something out of use, especially in the Present and Imperfect Tenses, and instead of it, the French do commonly make use of the Verb Entendre, which signifies both to hear and to understand.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. J'Oy, tu ois, il oit, &c. J'oyois, j'ouis.
J'ay ouÃ¯, j'avois ouÃ¯, j'eu ouÃ¯.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: J'aye ouÃ¯, j'aurois ouÃ¯, j'eusse ouÃ¯, j'aurai ouÃ¯.
The Imperative is quite out of use.
Infinitive, OuÃ¯r, Avoir OuÃ¯, Oyant, OuÃ¯.

div.head: 14. Partir, To Depart, or, to go away.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE pars, tu pars, il part.
P. Nous partons, vous partez, ils partent.
Je suis parti, j'Ã©tois parti, je fus parti.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE je parte, tu partes, &c.
Je sois parti, je serois parti, je fusse parti, je serai parti.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. PArs, qu'il parte. P. partons, partez, qu'ils partent.

div.p: And so are Conjugated its Compounds Repartir, &c.

div.head: 15. Puir, To stink.
div.p: This Verb has nothing that is in use, but the Indicative's present, sometimes the Singular of the Imperfect, and the Participle present in Ant; as,
Je pus, tu pus, il put, nous puons, vous puez, ils puent.
Je puois, tu puois, il puoit. Puant; Instead of PuÃ¯r, the French use, Sentir mauvais, or, Erre puant.

div.head: 16. Querir, To fetch.
div.p: This Verb has nothing in use but the Infinitive, nor this neither, without one of these three Verbs, Aller, Venir, Envoyer before it; but its Compounds, Acquerir, to acquire, or, to purchase. Conquerir, to Conquer, and Requerir, to require, are thus Conjugated.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. J'Acquiers, tu acquiers, il acquiert.
P. Nous acquerons, vous acquerez, ils acquierent.
J'ais acquis, j'avois acquis, j'eu acquis.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE j'acquiere, tu acquieres, il acquiere.
P. Nous acquerions, vous acqueriez, ils acquierent.
J'aye acquis, j'aurois acquis, j'eusse acquis, j'aurai acquis.

div.p: And so is Conjugated Requerir: But Conquerir in the Present Tense, both of the Indicative and Conjunctive, has but the first and second Persons in the Plural, Nous Conquerons, vous Conquerez, Que nous Conquerions, vous Conqueri â€¢ z. And in the Imperative, Conquerons, Conquerez, all the rest is like Acquerir.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE me repens, tu be repens, il se repent.
P. Nous nous repentons, vous vous repentez, ils se repentent.
Je me repentois, je me repentis.
Je me suis repenti, je m'Ã©tois repenti, je me fus repenti.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: Je me repentirois, je me repentisse.
Je me sois repenti, je me serois repenti, je me fusse repenti, je me serai repenti.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. REpen toi, qu'il se repente.
P. Repentons nous, repentez vous, qu'ils se repentent.

list.head: Infinitive.
list.item: SE Repentir, s'Ã©tre repenti. Se repentant, repenti.

div.head: 18. Sentir, To feel, To smell.
div.p:
This Verb and its Compounds, Consentir, to consent, Ressentir, to resent, Presentir, to perceive beforehand, are Conjugated
like Se Repentir, except that their Compound Tenss take the Verb Avoir, instead of Etre. Thus, Iai Senti, I'avois Senti, &c.

div.head: 19. Servir, To serve.
div.p: This Verb and its Compounds are Conjugated like Dormir, to sleep.

div.head: 20. Sortir, To go out.
div.p: This Verb and its Compounds are Conjugated as Dormir, but that in their Compound Tenses they have the Verb Etre, instead of Avoir.

div.head: 21. Souffrir, To suffer.
div.p: This Verb is Conjugated like Couvrir, to cover.

div.head: 22. Tenir, To hold.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE tiens, tu tiens, ils tient.
P. Nous tenons, vous tenez, ils tiennent.
S. Je tins, tu tins, il tint.
P. Nous timmes, vous tintes, ils tinrent.
J'ay tenu, j'avois tenu, j'eu tenu.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: J'aye tenu, j'aurois tenu, J'eusse tenu, j'aurai tenu.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. TIen, qu'il tienne. P. Tenons, Tenez, qu'ils tiennent.

div.p: And so are Conjugated its Compounds, Appartenir, to belong, Contenir, to contain.

div.head: 23. Venir, To come.
div.p: Venir, to come, Devenir, to become, Revenir, to come again, Survenir, to come upon, are Conjugated like Tenir, except their Compound Tenses, which take the Verb Etre. As for the other Compounds of Venir, viz. Convenir, to agree, Contrevenir, to Contravene, Prevenir, to prevent, and Subvenir, to relieve, they are Conjugated like Tenir.

div.head: 24. VÃ©tir, To put on.
div.p: This Verb is little used but in its Compound Tenses; as, I'ay vÃ©tu, j'avois vÃ©tu, &c. yet it is used sometimes in the Imperative; as, VÃ©tez cet habit, put on that suit of Cloaths, it is Conjugated thus.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE vets, tu vets, il vet, P. Nous vÃªtons, vous vÃªtez, ils vÃªtent.
J'ay vÃªtu, j'avois vÃªtu, j'eu vÃªtu.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: J'aye vÃªtu, j'aurois vÃªtu, j'eusse vÃªtu, j'aurai vÃªtu.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: S. VEts, qu'il vÃªte. P. vÃªtons, vÃªtez, qu'ils vÃªtent.

div.p: Its Compound RevÃªtir, to put on, is so Conjugated, and is something more in use. But, Travestir, to Disguise, and Investir, to Invest, or to Surround, are regular.
Â§. 3. Irregular Verbs of the Third Conjugation.
The third Conjugation hath 19 Irregular Verbs.

div.head: 1. Avoir, To have.
div.p: This Verb is the first of the Auxiliary Verbs, of which you have had the full Conjugation already.

div.head: 2. Cheoir, or, Choir, To fall.
div.p: This Verb is so grown out of date, that if any Tense of it may be used, these two must be them, Ie cheus, I fell, and je suis chu, I am fallen. As for all other Tenses 'tis best to make use of Tomber. But it has two Compounds, Dechoir, to decay or to waste, and Echoir, to expire, of which the former is thus Conjugated.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. Je dechois, to dechois, il dechoit. P. Nous decheons, vous decheez, ils decheent.
Je suis dechÃ», J'Ã©tois dechÃ», je fus dechÃ».

list.head: Conjunctive. Presentâ–ª
list.item: S. QUE je dechÃ©e, tu dechÃ©es, il dechÃ©e.
P. Nous decheions, vous decheiez, ils dechÃ©ent.
Je sois dechu, je serois dechu, je fusse dechu, je serai dechu.

div.p: As for Ã©choir, it is only used impersonally; as, Il Ã©choit it happens, it falls out, it expires, Il Ã©chÃ©oit, il Ã©chut, &c.

div.head: 3. Mouvoir, To move.
div.p: This Verb is quite worn out, and instead of it the French use remÃ¼er, but its Compound Emouvoir, which signifies the same thing, is very frequent, and is thus Conjugated.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. J'Emeus, tu Ã©meus, il Ã©meut.
P. Nous Ã©mouvons, vous Ã©mouvez, ils Ã©meuvent.
J'ai Ã©mÃ», j'avois Ã©mÃ», j'eu Ã©mÃ».

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: J'aye Ã©mÃ», j'aurois Ã©mÃ», j'eusse Ã©mÃ», j'aurai Ã©mÃ».

div.head: 4. Pleuvoir, To Rain.
div.p: This Verb is Impersonal, and is thus Conjugated.

list.head: Indicative.
list.item: IL pleut, il pleuvoit, il pleut.
Il a pleu, il avoit pleu, il cut pleu.

list.head: Conjunctive.
list.item: QU'il pleuve, il pleuvroit, il plust.
Il ait plÃ», il auroit plÃ», il eust plÃ», il aura plÃ».

div.head: 5. Pouvoir, To be able, or, Can.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE puis, tu peus, il peut.
P. Nous pouvons, vous pouvez, â€¢ ls peuvent.
J'ay p â€¢ , j'avois pÃ», j'eu pÃ».

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: J'aye pÃ», j'aurois pÃ», j'eusse pÃ», j'aurai pÃ».

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE sai, tu sais, il sait.
Pâ–ª Nous savons, vous savez, ils savent.
J'ai sÃ», j'avois sÃ», j'eu sÃ».

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE je sache, tu saches, il sache.
P. Nous sachions, vous sachiez, ils sachent.
J'aye sÃ», j'aurois sÃ», j'eusse sÃ», j'aurai sÃ».

div.head: 7. Valoir, To be Worth.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE vaus, tu vaus, il vaut.
P. Nous valons, vous valez, ils valent.
Jai valu, j'avois valu, j'eu valu.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: J'aye valu, j'aurois valu, j'eusse valu, j'aurai valu.

div.p: And so Conjugate Prevaloir, to prevail.

div.head: 8. Voir, To see.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE vois, tu vois, il voit.
P. Nous voyons, vous voyez, ils voyent.
J'ai veu, j'avois veu, j'eu veu.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: J'aye veu, j'aurois veu j'eusse veu, j'aurai veu.

div.p: And so Conjugate its Compounds, Entrevoir, to have a glimpse of. Prevoir, to foresee. Pourvoir, to provide. Revoir, to see again.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE veux, tu veux, il veut.
P. Nous voulons, vous voulez, ils veulent.
J'ai voulu, j'avois voulu, j'eu voulu.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE je veuille, tu veuilles, il veuille.
P. Nous voulions, vous vouliez, ils veuillent.
J'aye voulu, j'aurois voulu, j'eusse voulu, j'aurai voulu.

div.head: 10. Seoir, To sit down.
div.p: This Verb is scarce ever used, instead of it, the French make use of Assoir, which has the same Signification, and is thus Conjugated.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE m'assieds, tu t'assi â€¢ ds, il s'assied.
P. Nous nous asseyons, vous vous asseyez, ils s'asseyent.
Je me suis assis, je m'Ã©tois assis, je me fus assis.
Je m'assoirai, or, je m'assierai, or, je m'assirai, &c.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: Je me sois assis, je me serois assis, je me fusse assis, je me serai assis.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: P. Asseyons nous, asseyez vous, qu'ils s'asseyent.

div.p: Seoir, has another Compound, viz. Sursoir, to delay, to put off, which is Conjugated as Assoir.

div.head: Â§. 4. Irregular Verbs of the fourth Conjugation.
div.p: The fourth Conjugation has 27 Irregular Verbs, viz.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE bats, tu bats, il bat.
P. Nous battons, vous battez, ils battent.
Je batois, je battis, j'ay batu, &c.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE bois, tu bois, il boit.
P. Nous beuvons, vous beuvez, ils boivent.
Je beuvois, je bus, j'ai bÃ», &c.

list.head: Conjunctive. Present.
list.item: S. QUE je boive, tu boives, il boive.
P. Nous beuvions, vous beuvi â€¢ z, ils boivent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: BOI, qu'il boive, beuvons, beuvez, qu'ils boivent.

div.head: 3. Braire, Comme un Ane, To Bray.
div.p: This Verb is seldom in use but in the third Person. However it may be thus Conjugated.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE brais, tu brais, il brait.
P. Nous brayons, vous brayez, ils brayent.

div.head: 4. Clorre, To shut.
div.p: This Verb and its Compounds Eclorre, to hatch, Enclorre, to inclose, are never used but in the Infinitive, and in the Participle passive, Clos Close, Eclos Eclose.
As for the Verbs Conclurre to conclude, Exclurre to exclude, inclurre to inclose, which derive from Clorre, they are thus Conjugated.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE conclus, tu conclus, il conclut.
P. concluons, vous concluez, ils concluent.
Je concluois, je conclus, j'ai conclu, &c.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: COnclu, qu'il concluÃ«, concluons, concluez, qu'ils concluent.

div.head: 5. Connoitre, To know.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE connois, tu connois, il connoit.
P. Nous connoissons, vous connoissez, ils connoissent.
Je connoissois, je connus, j'ai connu, &c.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: COnnoi, qu'il connoisse, connoissons, connoissez, qu'ils connoissent.

div.p: And so are Conjugated its Compounds Mecon â€¢ oitre to mistake, and Reconnoitre to acknowledge, or, to know again.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE construis, tu construis, il construit.
P. Nous construisons, vous construisez, ils construisent.
Je construisois, je construisis, j'ay construit, &c.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: COnstrui, qu'il construise, construisons, construisez, qu'ils construisent.

div.head: 7. Coudre, To sow.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE cous, tu cous, il cout.
P. Nous cousons, vous cousez, ils cousent.

J'ay cousu, &c. Je coudrai,
â€¢ c.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: COus, qu'il couse, cousons, cousez, qu'ils cousent.

div.p: And so Conjugate its Compounds, Decoudre, to unsowâ–ª Recoudre, to sow again.

div.head: 8. Croire, To believe.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE crois, tu crois, il croit.
P. Nous croyons, vous croyez, ils croyent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: CRoi, qu'il croye, croyons, croyez, qu'ils croyent.

div.p: * The Dipthongue oi, in this Verb is commonly pronounced like an (e) open. And instead of Croyons, Croyez, je Croyois, je Croye. We often say, Creyons, Creyez, je Creyois, je Creye, &c.

div.head: 9. Croitre, To grow.
div.p: This Verb and its Compounds, Accroitre, to increase, &c. are Conjugated as Connoitre.

div.head: 10. Cuire, To Roast, to Boil, or to Bake
div.p: This Verb and its Compounds, Recuire are Conjugated as Construire.

div.head: 11. Detruire, To destroy.
div.p: This Verb is Conjugated like Construire.

div.head: 12. Dire, To say.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE dis, tu dis, il dit.
P. Nous disons, vous dites, ils disent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: DI, qu'il dise, disons, dites, qu'ils disent.

div.p: And so Conjugate its Compounds, Maudire, to Curse, Predire, to foretel, &c. Except that Maudire in the Plural of the Present Indicative, is thus Conjugated, Nous Maudissons, vous Maudissez, ils Maudissent.

div.head: 13. Ecrire, To Write.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. J'Ecris, tu Ã©cris, il Ã©crit.
P. Nous Ã©crivons, vous Ã©crivez, ils Ã©crivent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: ECri, qu'il Ã©crive, Ã©crivons, Ã©crivez, qu'ils Ã©crivent.

div.p: And so are Conjugated its Compounds, DÃ©crire, to describe, Prescrire, to prescribe, &c.

div.head: 14. Faire, To do, or, to make.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE fais, tu fais, il fait.
P. Nous faisons, vous faites, ils font.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: FAis, qu'il fasse, faisons, faites, qu'ils fassent.

div.p: Thus are Conjugated all its Compounds, Contrefaire, to Counterfeit, Defaire, to undo, &c.
*These two Verbs, Confire, to Candy. Suffire, to suffice, which derive from Faire, are Conjugated like Dire to say, except that Suffire has I'ai Suffi, without a (t) in all the Compound Tenses.

div.head: 15. Lire, To Read.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item:
P.
ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ vous lisez, ils ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ .

J'ay lÃ», & â€¢ .
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ Je lirai, &c.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: LIS, qu'il lise, lisons, lisez, qu'ils lisent.

div.p: In the same manner are Conjugated Elire, to Elect, Relire, to read again.

div.head: 16. Luire, To Shine.
div.p: This Verb is Conjugated at Cuire, but that its Preter perfect is j'ai lui.

div.head: 17. Mettre, to put, to lay.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE mets, tu mets, il met.
P. Nous mettons, vous mettez, ils mettent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: MEts, qu'il mette, mettons, mettez, qu'ils mettent.

div.p: And so are Conjugated its Compounds, Commettre, to commit, &c.

div.head: 18. Moudre, To grind.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE mouls, tu mouls, il moult.
P. Nous moulons, vous moulez, ils moulent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: MOuls, qu'il moule, moulons, moulez, qu'ils moulent.

div.p: Thus are Conjugated its Compounds, Remoudre, to grind again, &c.

div.head: 19. Naitre, To be Born.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE nais, tu nais, il nait.
P. Nous naisons, vous naissez, ils naissent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: NAis, qu'il naisse, naissons, naissez, qu'ils naissent.

div.p: And thus may be Conjugated its Compound, Renaitre, to be born again, but that it has no Compound Tenses.

div.head: 20. Nuire, To hurt, to anoy.
div.p: This Verb is Conjugated as Construire, but that its Preter perfect is I'ai nui.

div.head: 21. Paitre, To feed.
div.p: This Verb is Conjugated as Naitre, but that it has no Compound Tenses; its Compound, Repaitre, to feed, is Conjugated thus.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE repais, tu repais, il repait.
P. Nous repaissons. vous repaissez, ils repaissent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: REpais, qu'il repaisse, repaissons, repaissez, qu'ils repaissent.

div.head: 22. Paroitre, To appear.
div.p: This Verb and its Compounds, Disparoitre, to disappear, &c. are Conjugated, as ConnoÃ®tre.

div.head: 23. Plaire, to please.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE plais, tu plais, il plait.
P. Nous plaisons, vous plaisez, ils plaisent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: PLais, qu'il plaise, plaisons, plaisez, qu'ils plaisent.

div.p: And so its Compound Deplaire, to displease, is Conjugated. As for Complaire, to be complaisant, it is only used in the Infinitive.

div.head: 24. Prendre, To take.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. Je prens, tu prens, il prent.
P. Nous prenons, vous prenez, ils prenent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: PRen, qu'il prene, prenons, prenez, qu'ils prenent.

div.p: Thus are Conjugated its Compounds, Apprendre, to learn, Comprendre, to apprehend, &c.

div.head: 25. Rire, To laugh.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE ris, tu ris, il rit.
P. Nous rions, vous riez, ils rient.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: RI, qu'il rie, rions, riez, qu'ils rient.

div.p: And so is Conjugated SoÃ»rire, to smile.

div.head: 26. Suivre, To follow.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE suis, tu suis, il suit.
P. Nous suivons, vous suivez, ils suivent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: SUI, qu'il suive, suivons, suivez, qu'ils suivent.

div.p: Thus are Conjugated its Compounds, Poursuivre, to follow, &c.

div.head: 27. Vivre, To live.

list.head: Indicative. Present.
list.item: S. JE vis, tu vis, il vit.
P. Nous vivons, vous vivez, ils vivent.

list.head: Imperative.
list.item: VI, qu'il vive, vivons, vivez, qu'ils vivent.

div.p: Thus are Conjugated its Compounds, Revivre, to come to life again, and Survivre, to out-live.

div.head: Of the way of Conjugating Verbs with an Interrogation, with a Negation, with an Interrogation and Negation together, and with these Particles en and y.
div.p: 1. THE way to Conjugate a Verb with an Interrogation, is to put the Personal Pronoun after the Verb; as,

Aime je? do I love? aimez vous? do you love? aime t- â€¢ lle? doe â€¢
she love? vas tu? do you go? va- â€¢ -il? does he go? vont il â€¢
â–ª
do they go? nous levons nous? do we rise? se levent elles? do they rise? pleut il? does it rain? aime-t-on? do they love?

2. To Conjugate a Verb with a Negation, the Frenc â€¢
make commonly use of two Negative Particles, vis. ne an â€¢
pas, the first goes betwixt the Person and the Verb, an â€¢
pas after the Verb; Thus,

Ie ne parle pas, I do not speak; Vous ne parlez pas, yo â€¢
speak not; Ie ne me leve pas, I do not rise; Elle ne s â€¢â€¢ leve pas, she does not rise; Il ne gelÃ© pas, it does not freeze:
3. Now when there is an Interrogation with a Negation together, ne goes before the Verb, and pas after the Verb and the Pronoun; as,
Ne vous levez vous pas? do you not rise? Ne parle t-elle pas? doth she not speak? Ne pleut il pas? does it not rain.

But the Particle ne is sometimes left out, especially before the Verbs beginning with a Con â€¢ onant; as,
Le Roi veut il faire cela? will not the King do that?
La Princesse partira-t-elle pas demain? will not the Princess go away to morrow?
* Note that the Imperative Mood cannot be used with an Interrogation, but in the Negative it may; as,
Ne parle pas, do not speak; Quelle ne dise rie â€¢ , let her say nothing.

4. As for the two Particles en and y they come between the Person, and the Verb, where the Verb is used without an Interrogation; as,
I'en parle, I speak of it; Elles en parlent, they speak of it.
Tu y vas, thou goest thither; Vous y irez, you shall go thither.
But in the Imperative Mood they run thus.
Parles-en, do thou speak of it; Vas y, do thou go thither.
Qu'il en parle, let him speak of it; Qu'elle-y-aille, let her go thither.
If the Negatives come in with these Particles, then they must be placed as followeth;
Ie n'en parle pas? I speak not of it? Ie n'y vai pas, I do not go thither; Ie n'en ai pas parl â€¢ , I did not speak of it; Ie n'y suis pas allÃ©, I did not go thither.
But, if with these Particles, a Verb be used with an Interrogation, it must be thus,
N'en parle je pas? do I not speak of it?
N'y allons nous pas? do we not go thither?

div.head: ART. V.
Of Participles.
div.p: THE Participle is a Part of Speech, so called, because it partaketh something of a Noun and something of a Verb.

The Participles besides the Nature of a Noun Adjective (or Substantive,) has the signification of the Verb from which it derives, and these two Tenses, the Present, and the Preter, from whence comes the division of Participles, into Participles of the Present, and others of the Preter Tense.

div.head: 1. Participles of the Present Tense.
div.p: All Participles present in French, end in ant, and are thus formed from the Infinitive of Verbs.
In the First Conjugation, by turning er into ant, Parler, parlant.
In the Second Conjugation, by turning er into issant, Emplir, Emplissant.
In the Third Conjugation, by turning oir into ant, Recevoir, Recevant.
In the Fourth, this Participle is formed from the first person plural of the Present Tense of the Indicative, changing ons into ant, Craign â€¢ ns, Craignant, Vendons, Vendant.
â€ Except the Irregular Verbs of the three last Conjugations which form their Participles Present, as you may see in the List of Irregular Verbs.

div.head: Construction of Participles Present.
div.p:
The Participle in ant, never varies as long as it has the force and Signification of the Verb it derives from, but is of all Numbers and Genders; as,
Le Soleil Ã©chauffant â€¢ a Terre, &c. The Sun warming the Earth, &c.
La Lune luisant dans la nuit. The Moon shining in the Night.
Les Etoiles Brillant dans une nuit obscure. The Stars Sparkling in a dark night.
Le Roy Ã©tant assis sur son Throne. The King sitting on his Throne.
La Reine Ã©tant malade. The Queen being sick.
Ces Dames Ã©tant un peu dÃ©licates. Those Ladies being a little nice.

But when the Participles present takes the form of a Noun, then it varies according to the difference of Genders, and Numbers; as,
Vn homme brillant, A man of a brisk and lively humour.
Vn beautÃ© charmante, A charming beauty.
Les Etoiles Ã©tincelantes, The sparkling Stars.
Vn grand panchant au vice, A great proneness to vice.
Vne servante adroite, A cunning and handy Maid.
Le croissant de la Lune, The increase of the Moon.

To conclude, this Participle is often Construed with the Preposition en; as,
E â€¢ parlant de la â€¢ uerre nous dÃ®mes beaucoup de choses touchant les conquÃªtes du Roy.
As we were speaking of the War, we said many things about the Kings Conquests.
Elle m'avoÃ¼a en soupirant qu'elle vous aimoit.
She confess'd to me with a sigh, that she loved you.

div.head: 2. Participles of the Preter Tense.
div.p: These Participles are generally formed from the Infinitive Mood.
In the First Conjugation by changing er in Ã©, Parler, ParlÃ©.

In the Second Conjugation by changing ir in i, Empli â€¢
Empli
In the Third Conjugation by putting away oir Recevoir, Receu.
In the Fourth Conjugation by changing re into u, as Vendre, Vendu.
â€ Except the Irregular Verbs of the three last Conjugations whose Participles Preter have several endings, as you may see in the Conjugation of Irregular Verbs.

div.head: Construction of Participles Preter.
div.p: The Participle Preter being used in the active Signification with the Auxiliary Avoir, never changes, but is of all Genders, Numbers, and Persons; as,

list.item: Tu as aimÃ©. Thou hast loved.
Elle a aimÃ©. She has loved.
Nous avons aimÃ©. We have loved.
Vous aviez aimÃ©. You had loved.
Ils auront aimÃ©. They shall have loved.

div.p: â€ Yet when these Pronouns Que, Le, La, Les, go before this Participle, then the Participle must agree with the Pronoun, both in Gender, and Number; as,

Le livre que j'ai lÃ». The Book which I have read; La Lettre que j'ai veÃ¼e, The Letter I have seen; Les Dames que j'ai salÃ¼Ã©es, The Ladies which I bowed to; Ie l'ai veu, I have seen him; Ie l'ai veÃ¼e, I have seen her; Ie les ai emplis, I have filled them; Ie les ai emplies, I have filled them.
The Participle Preter used in the Passive and Reciprocal Signification, varies according to the difference of Genders and Numbers, as you have seen in the Conjugation of Verbs.
The Gender Feminine is formed from the Masculine, by adding an e. Feminine; as,
AimÃ©, AimÃ©e, loved. Empli, Emplie, filled, &c.
The Plural Number Masculine in the first Conjugation is formed â€¢ from the Singular, by adding a (z) and putting away the Accent, or, by adding an (s) and keeping the Accent; as,
AimÃ©, Aimezâ–ª or, AimÃ©s, in the other three it is formed by adding an (s) only; as, Empli, Emplis, filled, &c.
The Plural Number Feminine is formed from the Singular, by the sole addition of an (s); as,
AimÃ©e, AimÃ©es, loved. Emplie, Emplies, filled.
* Note that when the Pronoun (vous) is put for the Singular, (tu) the Participle Past that follows it, is put in the Singular; as,
Vous Ã©tes aimÃ© ou aimÃ©e, You are loved.

div.head: ART. VI.
Of Adverbs.
div.p:
AN Adverb is a part of Speech, which being joyned with the Verbs, and sometimes with the Nouns, explains, or fills up their Signification; as,
Cette Dame chante divinement, That Lady sings divinely.
Elle est extrÃ©mement belle, She is extreamly handsome.

* Every Adverb is not express'd in one word; but some of them consist of a Preposition and a Noun, as Ã l'impreveu, unawares, and others of a Preposition and an Adverbâ–ª as, vis-Ã -vis, over against, &c.
Now there are several sorts of Adverbs, and First.

list.item: A cette heure, at this time.
Dans ce moment, at this moment.
Depuis peu, Nagueres, not long since.
Dans peu, within a little while.
L'an qui vient, the next year.
De jour, in the day time.

Tard, trop tard, late, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
late.

DeÃ§a, delÃ , on this side, on that side.
De cÃ´tÃ© & d'autre, up and down.
De tous cÃ´tez, on every side.
Tout au tour, round, round about.
De quel endroit, from what place.
Tant soit peu, but a little.

Tant, autant, so much, as much.
Tout au plus, at the most.
A tout le moins, at least.

that.

mind.

div.p: * Most of the Adverbs of Quality in French, are formed from Nouns Adjective of the Feminine Gender, by adding ment; as,

list.item: Royale, Royalement. Bonne, Bonnement. Grande, Grandement.
Royal, Royally. Good, Ingenuously. Great, Greatly.

div.p: But that Rule has four Exceptions.

â€ 1. If the Noun Adjectiue be of the common Gender, the Adverb is formed by adding ment only; as, from Iuste, utile, just, useful, comes Iustement, utilement, which have always an (e) Feminine before ment, except these which have an (Ã©) Masculine.

â€ 2. If the Nown Adjective ends by an (Ã©) Masculine, by an (i) or by an (u), the Adverb is formed of the Masculine, and not of the Feminine; as, from AssurÃ©, joliâ–ª res â€¢ lu, comes AssurÃ©ment, assuredly, joliment, prettily, resolument, resolutely.

â€ 3. Nouns Adjectives ending in ant or ent, form their Adverbs by changing nt in
â€¢ , and adding ment, as from Constant, Prudent, comes Constainment, constantly, Prude â€¢
ment, prudently.

â€ 4. Finally Nouns Adjectives ending in ment; as Vehement, Clement, have no Adverbs, and instead of Veheme â€¢â€¢
ment, and Clememment, we say avec Clemence, with Clemency, avec Vehemence, with vehemency.
Iustement, justly, Plus justement, more justly, Le plus justement, most justly.

div.head: ART. VII.
Of Conjunctions.
div.p: A Conjunction is a part of Speech that serves to joyn Words, Sentences, and Periods together.
Conjunctions are divided into several Orders, of which some are.

list.item: Et, and. Aussi, also. Encore, yet, still. Deplus, Davantage, moreover. Au reste, for the rest. Enfin, in fine, or, now.
Soitque, whether, or, Encore que, tho', when.

div.head: 3. Adversative, i. e. Shewing some Contrariety.

list.item: Si est ce que, but for all that.
A condition que, upon condition that.

div.head: 5. Causal, or, giving reason of what is said.

list.item: Pour cet effet, to that end.
Au reste, as for the rest.
Or, or est il, now, now since.

div.p: * Observe that there is so great affinity an between Adverbs and Conjunctions, that it is very hard sometimes to distinguish them from one another: And besides, Conjunctions being used in several Senses, have also several Names: But 'ti smuch more profitable to know all these petty differences by the reading of good Authors, than by any Rules of Grammar.

div.head: ART VIII.
Of Prepositions.
div.p: A Preposition is a part of Speech which goes before the other parts to explain their various Signification.
Prepositions are divided into Separable and Inseparable.
A separable Preposition is commonly separated from other words, and signifies something by it self; as, Dans in, Avec with.
An inseparable is never found but in Compound words, and signifies nothing of it self; as, Ad-mettre, to admit, E-taller, to shew, Im-poser, to impose.

* Most of these Compound words deriving from the Latin, to shew the true nature of inseparable Prepositions, it would be requisite to consider each of them singly, and to dive into the Latin for their Signification, but that being quite out of our purpose, and besides of no use, I shall give you the List of the separable.

list.item: DE, du, dela, des, Of, from.
Au milieu, au mitan, in the middle.
Sur, sus, dessus, au dessus, up, upon.
A fleur de terre, close to the ground.
A fleur d'eau, even with the water.
A la maniere, after the manner.
A la mode, after the fashion.
A raison de, at the rate of.
Derr â€¢ ere, au derriere, behind.
Dans, dedans, au dedans, en, in, within.
Hors, dehors, au dehors, out without.
A travers, au travers, cross, through.
Jusque, jusques, till, to, even to.

div.head: ART. IX.
Of Interjections.
div.p: AN Interjection is a part of Speech expressing a sudden motion of the mind, such as are,

list.item: â€¢ a, courage, come, cheer up.
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.
Ah mon Dieu! oh my God!
Ai! ah! ouf! ai! oh! oh! O Ciel! oh Heaven!
Or, sus, Ã§a, sus donc, marche, come on.
Gare, prenez garde, have a care.
Hola ho, hola hei, ho there, ho hey.
Ouaih! voyez! lack a day! see!
Fi, fi, pouah, Fie, fie, soughâ–ª
Fi le pouacre, fie upon, faugh.
Foin de vous, fie upon you.
Au diantre, dew â€¢ e take.
Des nÃ©fles, des sottises, â€¢ agatelles, trifles, away, silly stuff.
Ha, ha, he, hi, hi, hi, ah, ah, eh, eh.
Chut, st, st, hush, not a word.
Paix, paix lÃ , pea â€¢ e there.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of Sentences. Or, The Construction of words, called, Syntax.
div.p: HAving explained in the foregoing Chapter, the nine Parts of Speech, each by it self, I come now to the Syntax, which is the Construction of them together, into Sentences, according to right use.

'Tis true, that a great deal of this has been already treated of, in the Exposition of the parts of Speech: But because something more may be said, of no small use, I shall give you the following Rules.

div.head: 1. Rule.
div.p: The Article, the Noun Adjective, the Pronoun, and the Participle, agree with the Noun Substantive, both in Number and Gender; as,

Le grand lit, The great bed; La grande table, The great table; Les beaux hommes, les belles femmes, The handsome men; the handsome women; L'homme blessÃ©, The wounded man; Vne femme aimÃ©e, a woman loved; Vn Prince charmant, a Charming Prince; Vne Princesse charmante, a charming Princess; Mon Prince & ma Princesse, My Prince and my Princess.

*But Note, that in the use of these Pronouns Possessive, mon, ton, son, the French mind less the strictness of the Rule, than the sweetness of the Language; And so they say, Mon ame, my Soul, Ton EpÃ©e, thy Sword, Son amie, his or her friend, altho' Ame, epÃ©e, amie, be of the Feminine Gender, and mon, ton, son, of the Masculine.

div.head: 2. Rule.
div.p: Two or more Nouns Substantive in the Singular Number being joyned together by a Conjunction, are as good as a Plural Number; and therefore if a Verb and an Adjective come after them, both these must be put in the Plural Number; as,
Le Pere & le fils sont malheureux, The Father and the Son are unfortunate; La mere & la fille sont Ã©galement belles, The Mother and the Daughter are equally handsome.

div.head: 3. Rule.
div.p: If one of the Substantives be of the Masculine Gender, and the other of the Feminine, the Adjective Plural that goes along with the Verb, will be also of the Masculine; as,
Les hommes & les femmes sont mortels, Both Men and Women are mortal.

div.head: 4. Rule.
div.p:
But if there comes no Verb after two Substantives of a different Gender, then the Adjective agrees with the last, both in Number and Gender; as,
I' ai le coeur & la main ouverte pour vous recevoir.
My heart and hand are open to receive you.
On voit souvent le merite, l'honneur & la justice opprimÃ©e.
We often see merit, honour, and justice opprest.
* Note that these two words Quelque chose, something, tho' of the Feminine Gender, will have the Adjective that comes after, relating to them, in the Masculine Gender; as,
Sa Conversation a quelque chose d'ennuyeux, His Conversation is somewhat tedious.

div.head: 5. Rule.
div.p:
All Pronouns Relative, such as il, elle, qui, quel, quelle, &c. agree with their Antecedent, both in Number and Gender; as,
C'est la Dame pour laquelle j'ai tant d'estime & damitiÃ©.
That's the Lady I have so much esteem and kindness for.
C'est vÃ´tre mari & v â€¢ us devez le respecter.
He is your Husband and you ought to respect him.

div.head: 6. Rule.
div.p:
A Verb Personal being joyned with a Substantive, agrees with it in Number and Person; as,
L'amour de Dieu contient toutes les autres vertus.
The Love of God comprehends all other Vertues.
Les Ã¢vantages de la nature sont prÃ©fÃ©rables Ã ceux de l â€¢ fortune.
The advantages of nature are preferable to those of fortune.

Note that all Nouns both Singular and Plural are of the third Person, except these Pronouns Personal, Ie, nous, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , vous, which are of the first and second: And all Nouns which are joyned with the first or second Persons of the Imperative Mood; as,

I' aime la vertu, I love vertue; Nous haÃ¯ssons le viceâ–ª we hate vice; Tu caquettes comme une Pie, thou twatlest like a Mag-Pye; Vous Ã©tes heureux, you are happy; Camarade, s â€¢ i moy, follow me, Friend; Monsieur Pierre, venez icy, Mr. Peter, come hither; Ayons bon courage, mes amis, Let's cheer up, Friends; Messieurs, songez Ã vous, Gentlemen, look to your selves.

div.head: 7. Rule.
div.p: The First Person is counted better than the Second, and the Second better than the Third; Therefore where two or three Persons go before a Verb, this agrees with the best Person; as,
Vous & moi Ã©tions fort en peine, you and I were very much troubled; Elle & moi nous promenames ensemble, she and I walked together; Vous & mon frere dinerez icy, you and my Brother shall dine here.

div.head: 8. Rule.
div.p:
After Collective words, such as Vne infinitÃ©, la plÃ»part, &c. the Verb agrees in Number with the Substantive that comes after the Collective; as,
Vne infinitÃ© de personnes me sont venus voir.
A great many people came to see me.
Vne infinitÃ© de monde m'est venu voir.
A world of people is come to see me.
La plÃ»part des hommes aiment la gloire.
Most men love glory.
La p â€¢ Ã»part du monde suit ses passions.
Most people follow their passions.

* It would be an easie matter for me to enlarge this Chapter of the Syntax, with several Observations upon the Idiom or Propriety of the French-Tongue: But as I have said before, I have made all along several Remarks upon the Construction of the Parts of Speech, to which, I think, it is enough to refer the Reader: For Experience convinces me, that most people learn much sooner how to Construe Words into Sentences, by the frequent reading of good Authors, and by an assiduous Practice, than by a cluster of Rules, which most commonly do but over-burden ones memory, without instructing the Understanding.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of Distinctions used in writing. VIZ. Accents, Stops, and Points.
div.p: AMongst the Distinctions used in Writing, some are proper to Vowels, others to Words and Sentences.

div.head: ART. I.
div.p: The Distinctions proper to Vowels, are three, viz.
1. The Accent (which is as the Soul of Words) is an elevation or rising of the Voice in one of the Syllables of a word.
The Accent is threefold, viz. Acute thus marked (Ã¡), Grave thus marked (Ã ), Circumflex thus marked (Ã¢).
The Acute shews the elevation of Syllables; the Grave denotes their falling or depression, and the Circumflex, both the rising and falling of the Syllable, which therefore ought to be a long one; as,
AutÃ©l, Altar. VertÃ¹, Virtue. ImpÃ´t, Tax.
* The Greek have been strict observers of Accents, in which they were in a great measure imitated by the Latin; but in all Modern Languages, the right use of them is little or not all understood.
The Acute in French, is peculiar to the Vowel, e.

list.item: 1. When the e is Masculine; as, PietÃ©, Piety. EpÃ©e, Sword.
2. When an s is left out because unpronounced; as, Ã©tre, to be, Ã©mouvoir, to move, formerly spelt estre, esmouvoir.

div.p: The Grave is peculiar to the Preposition Ã , to, and to the Adverbs lÃ , there, and oÃ¹, where; only for distinction sake, Ã from Ã hath, in the Verb avoir; lÃ , from la the, a Feminine Article and Pronoun; and oÃ¹ from the Conjunction ou, or.
The Circumflex is put upon any of the five Vowels, a, e, i, o, u, when any Vowel or Consonant is left out in the same Syllable, which the French do often in their new way of spelling; as,
Ã¢ge, age. AÃ»ne, yard. BÃ¢ton, stick. PÃ¢n, Peacock. Formerly spelt aage, aulne, baston, paon; and likewise,

QuÃªque for quelque, some; NiÃªce for Niepce, Neece; PrÃªtre for Prestre, Priest; ConoÃ®tre for Conoistre, to know; NÃ´tre for Nostre, our; CoÃ»teau for Cousteau, knife; bÃ» for beu, drunk; C â€¢ Ã» for Col, neck; foÃ» for fol, fool; genoÃ» for genouil, knee; fenoÃ» for fenouil, fennel.

II. By the division, I mean those two little points which are sometimes met with on the top of the Vowels, e, and i, to shew that the Vowel so marked, belongs not to the same Syllable, as the Vowel that is before it; as,
JouÃ«r, jouÃ¯r, to play, to enjoy.
which words consist of these two Syllables, jou-er, jou-ir.

III. An Apostroph (') is an inverted c, shewing that there is a Vowel wanting, and two words made into one, as it happens, when of two words, the first ends in one of these Vowels, a, e, i, and the next begins with any Vowel; as,
L'ame for la ame, the Soul, l'unitÃ© for la unitÃ©, the unityâ–ª
L'enfant for le enfant, the Child, s'il for si il, if he.
* To this purpose, see the IV. Article of the Second Chap.

div.head: ART. 2.
div.p: THE Distinctions proper to Words and Sentences, are eight in Number, viz.

list.item: 1. A Note of continuation thus marked -
6. A Note of interrogation thus marked ?
7. A Note of Admiration thus marked !

div.p:
1. A Note of Continuation (-) is made use of at the end of the line, when the word is divided betwixt that Line and the next, or else when two words are joined into one; as,
Mal-seant, unbecoming.
Vn Prince gÃ©nÃ©reux, doux, benin & communicatif est aimÃ© de tous ses Sujets. A Generous, Gentle, Kind and Affable Prince, is beloved of all his Subjects.
3. A Colon (:) marks a Sense that seems to be compleat, but so that there is still something to be added.
4. A Semicolon (;) marks a short member of a Sentence, which though it has a full sense of it self, yet contributes towards the making up of a compleat Period.
5. A Parenthesis ( â€¢ ) incloses within its two Figures a Sentence by it self, which may be used or omitted, and yet the Sence remain intire.
6. A note of Interrogation (?) is used where one asks a Question.
7. A note of Admiration (!) where one admires, or crys out for wonder.
8. A Period (.) shews that the Sense of the Sentence is full. Of all which you have an Example in the following Lines.

Ie vis cette belle personne Ã la promenade: la voir & l'aimer fÃ»t presque tout un, j'essayay (mais inutilement) D'Ã©touffer cette passion naissante; mais comment resister aux charmes de la beautÃ©? j'aimai donc; je trouvai le moyen d'entretenir mon Divin objet; & c'est ce qui acheva de me perdre; car ayant remarquÃ© tant d'Esprit, & tant de vertu dans cette aimable Personne, ma raison ne s'opposa plus Ã mon amour. Ma â€¢ s, O Malheur! lors que je commenÃ§ois Ã ne lui â€¢ Ã©tre pas indifferent la mort m'a ravi toutes mes esperances.

I saw that Charming Person a walking: To see her, and to love her was almost all one; I strived (but in vain) to stifle this rising Passion; but how can one resist the Powerful Charms of Beauty? I loved her; I found the way to discourse with her, and this was my utter ruin; for meeting with so much Wit, and so much Virtue in this Divine Creature, my Reason opposed my Love no longer. But, O Misfortune! When I begun not to be indifferent to her, Death robb'd me of all my hopes.
THE COMPLEAT French-Master.
The Second Part.

CONTAINING,
I. A Vocabulary.
II. The Familiar Dialogues.
III. The Niceties of the French-Tongue.
IV. Twelve Discourses by way of Conversation.

a plus de ressource.

div.head: XXXV. Dialogue.

div.p: QUi est la?

Attendez, Madame Suson vous Ã©tes si prompte lors qu'il saut aller parler au Laquaisâ€”

Vrayment, voilÃ qui a fort bonne grace, de me manquer ainsi de parole.

OÃ¼y, Madame.
